I can follow a logic that says, they'll adopt other Ripple offerings whilst XRP continues it's journey for legitimacy in the eyes of global regulators. I'd question whether we are at that point yet.

Creating a settlement asset requires a legal and regulatory framework, not just a technical one. I think that framework isn't in a place where many banks can get comfortable with it at scale. That said - other - non cryptocurrency related bits of the ripple offering they can
For example a lot of banks are reticent to hold anything on their balance sheet that resembles a cryptocurrency, not least since the European Banking Authority told them they can't.

All I ever questioned was the relative maturity of Ripple's solution and ability to solve that problem - vs perception / marketing / journalists confusing the various bits of the ripple offering. Redefining settlement is non trivial and requires acceptance

I see where it fits into their strategy, and after the last couple of days of 1,000 or so twitter mentions per day, see that even clearer. Ripple are trying to solve problems that are real and significant. I agree there's a problem.

The tweet isn’t geared at well informed skeptics. Here’s the point: if someone can’t answer a *basic* question, like “what is proof-of-work?,” or “how is bitcoin minted,” then they shouldn’t be mouthing off about bitcoin in the first place and it’s a waste of time to debate them

The rarest, and often most valuable thinkers in crypto right now are the well educated bears (or pessimists, skeptics, questioners, etc etc). Respect to them. No respect to people that speak without understanding first.

As with any tweet, the limited character space leads to over generalizations. My tweet is targeted at bears that clearly know little (or nothing) about bitcoin (e.g. Dimon, Munger, etc), but continue to pass judgment.
